title: Presidential transition of Richard Nixon
added: A presidential transition was guaranteed to occur in 1968 after incumbent president [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] opted against seeking reelection.

Ahead of the transition, Johnson appointed [[Charles S. Murphy]] as his transition officer, to head his administration's role in the pending transition.<ref name="Shribman"/> Johnson, while wanting his vice-president, [[Hubert Humphrey]], to win the election, expressed to confidents his desire to have a warm relationship and transition with Nixon if he were to win.<ref name="Shribman"/>

Six days after the election, Nixon and his wife [[Pat Nixon|Pat]] joined Johnson and his wife [[Lady Bird Johnson|Lady Bird]] at the White House.<ref name="Shribman"/> Nixon suggested to Johnson that he expected that, in his [[lame duck]] period, he would consult Nixon on significant matters, a notion that Johnson found disagreeable.<ref name="Shribman"/>

Johnson made available to Nixon use of the presidential aircraft.<ref name="Shribman"/> Nixon's advisers were granted office space across the road from the [[White House]], access to the White House [[telephone switchboard]], and automobiles.<ref name="Shribman"/>

The Nixon transition is considered by some to have been a smooth transition.<ref name="Shribman">{{cite web |last1=Shribman |first1=David M. |title=Opinion: After a bitter election in 1968, the transition came off without a hitch. We need a moment of national unity like that now. |url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/solutions/2020/12/03/after-bitter-election-1968-presidential-transition-smooth/3808058001/ |website=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel |access-date=5 February 2021 |date=3 December 2020}}</ref>

title: Presidential transition of Richard Nixon
added: On November 10, he met with [[United States Ambassador to South Vietnam]] [[Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.]] (who had previously been Nixon's own vice presidential running mate in the [[1960 United States presidential election|1960 election]]) to discuss Vietnam and peace talks.<ref name="GAO"/> On November 11, Nixon met with Johnson and others to discuss to potential for a peace agreement in Vietnam.<ref name="GAO"/>
*[[John Ehrlichman]] as Counsel to the President (November 14, 1968)<ref name="GAO"/>
*[[Bryce Harlow]] as Assistant to the President for Legislation and Congressional Affairs (announced November 12, 1968)<ref name="GAO"/>
*[[H. R. Haldeman]] as Assistant to the President (announced November 13, 1968)<ref name="GAO"/>

title: Presidential transition of Richard Nixon
added: ON January 6, Nixon announced that Lodge would be replacing Harriman as Chief U.S. Negotiator for Vietnamese peace talks once Nixon took office.<ref name="GAO"/>

title: Presidential transition of Richard Nixon
added: Early in his transition, Nixon spent time holding meetings with aides at a house he had rented from [[George Smathers]] in [[Biscayne Bay]], [[Florida]].<ref name="Semple1"/>
